description: Amid calls for raw data disclosure, Oksana Lintz proposes a different path: to launch citywide storytelling forums led by affected individuals and survivors, focusing on collective reconciliation instead of system exposure.
After an evening confiding in Alex, Oksana finalizes her choice: restrictions are set on BCI audit data, and invitations go out for curated memory forums across free zones.
The first guided storytelling gatherings take place, where residents share lived BCI experiences—both harm and hope—in open-air community circles. Interest and participation grow rapidly.

A local documentarian presents recovered footage from BCI pilot regions during a major forum, revealing early injustices and Halden’s struggles. This sparks wide public empathy and renewed interest in citywide healing.

Former Council members and ex-BCI designers attend forums, offering apologies and joining discussions on new, inclusive governance based on shared memory, trust, and reconciliation. The tone across Stenograd shifts from blame toward constructive debate on the city’s future.
